[latex]
div(\phi \mathrm{u})=\phi div(\mu)+ugrad(\phi)

question: Question 3 A remote village has exactly 1000 vehicles with sequential registration numbers starting from 1000 . Out of the total vehicles, [latex]30 \%[/latex] are without pollution clearance certificate. Further, even- and oddnumbered vehicles are operated on even- and oddnumbered dates, respectively. If 100 vehicles are chosen at random on an evennumbered date, the number of vehicles expected without pollution clearance certificate is.
solution: Since [latex]30 \%[/latex] of the total vehicles are without pollution clearance certificate. Out of the 100 chosen vehicle, [latex]30 \%[/latex] i.e. [latex]100 \times 0.3=30[/latex] vehicle are expected to be without pollution clearance certificate.

question: Question 5 M20 concrete as per IS 456: 2000 refers to concrete with a design mix having
solution: In M20, M refers to mix and 20 to characteristic cube strength. As per clause no. 6.1.1, IS456: 2000 characteristic strength is defined as the strength below which not more than 5 percent of the test results are expected to fall. Hence, correct option is (C).

question: Question 6 When a simply-supported elastic beam of span [latex]\mathrm{L}[/latex] and flexural rigidity [latex]EI ( E[/latex] is the modulus of elasticity and [latex]\mathrm{I}[/latex] is the moment of inertia of the section) is loaded with a uniformly distributed load [latex]w[/latex] per unit length, the deflection at the mid-span is [latex]\Delta_{0}=\frac{5}{384} \frac{w L^{4}}{\mathrm{El}}[/latex]. If the load on one half of the span is now removed, the mid-span deflection ____
solution: As Case-I and II are mirror image of each other,. Hence, [latex]\quad \Delta_{\mathrm{C}, 1}=\Delta_{\mathrm{C}, \mathrm{II}}[/latex] Also, [latex]\quad \Delta_{\mathrm{C}}=\Delta_{\mathrm{C}, 1}+\Delta_{\mathrm{C}, 1}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad \Delta_{\mathrm{C}, \mathrm{I}}=\Delta_{\mathrm{C}, \mathrm{II}}=\frac{\Delta_{\mathrm{C}}}{2}[/latex]

options.C: reduces to a value greater than [latex]\Delta_{0} / 2[/latex]

question: Question 7 Muller-Breslau principle is used in analysis of structures for
solution: Muller Breslass principle is used to draw influence line diagram for determinate and indeterminate structures. It states that influence line for any stress function may be obtained by removing the restraint offered by that function and introducing a directly related generalised unit displacement at that location in the direction of the stress function.

options.A: drawing an influence line diagram for any force response in the structure
options.B: writing the virtual work expression to get the equilibrium equation
options.C: superposing the load effects to get the total force response in the structure
options.D: relating the deflection between two points in a member with the curvature diagram inbetween

question: Question 8 A standard penetration test (SPT) was carried out at a location by using a manually operated hammer dropping system with [latex]50 \%[/latex] efficiency. The recorded SPT value at a particular depth is 28 . If an automatic hammer dropping system with [latex]70 \%[/latex] efficiency is used at the same location, the recorded SPT value will be
solution: We know that, Efficiency of blow [latex]\alpha \frac{1}{\text { SPT value }}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad \eta_{1} \mathrm{~N}_{1}=\eta_{2} \mathrm{~N}_{2}[/latex] Hence, [latex]0.50 \times 28=0.70 \times \mathrm{N}_{2}[/latex] or [latex]\quad \mathrm{N}_{2}=\frac{0.50 \times 28}{0.7}=20[/latex] Option (B) is correct

question: Question 9 A vertical sheet pile wall is installed in an anisotropic soil having coefficient of horizontal permeability, [latex]k_{H}[/latex] and coefficient of vertical permeability, [latex]k_{V}[/latex]. In order to draw the flow net for the isotropic condition, the embedment depth of the wall should be scaled by a factor of _____, without changing the horizontal scale.
solution:
We know that, for 2D flow. [latex]
\mathrm{K}=\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{x}} \frac{\partial^{2} \mathrm{~h}}{\mathrm{dx}}+\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{z}} \frac{\partial^{2} \mathrm{~h}}{\mathrm{dz}}=0
[/latex] When [latex]\mathrm{K}_{1}=\mathrm{K}_{\text {horizontal }}[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{K}_{2}=\mathrm{K}_{\text {vertical }}[/latex] as shown in figure. [latex]
\frac{\partial^{2} \mathrm{~h}}{\frac{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{z}}}{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{x}}} \partial \mathrm{x}^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2} \mathrm{~h}}{\partial \mathrm{z}^{2}}=0
[/latex] From the above equation we can note that, when soil is anisotropic with respect to permeability i.e. [latex]k_{x}=k_{z}[/latex], the flow and equipotential line are not necessarily to be orthogonal as because [latex]\frac{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{z}}}{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{x}}}=1[/latex], and we cannot get the actual form of Laplace equation which is [latex]\frac{\partial^{2} h}{\partial x^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2} h}{\partial z^{2}}=0[/latex]. But if we replace [latex]
x_{t}=x \sqrt{\frac{K_{z}}{\mathrm{~K}_{x}}}
[/latex] Then, [latex]\quad \partial x_{t}^{2}=\partial x^{2} \frac{K_{z}}{\mathrm{~K}_{x}}[/latex] [latex]
\frac{\partial^{2} h}{\partial x_{t}^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2} h}{\partial z^{2}}=0
[/latex] Thus, new flow line and equipotential lines are drawn on transformed section with [latex]\mathrm{x}[/latex]-distance changed to [latex]x \sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{z}}}{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{x}}}}[/latex] while keeping the vertical dimension constant. If we scale up the depth by keeping the horizontal distance same the depth will be scaled by factor [latex]\sqrt{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{x}} / \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{z}}}[/latex].

\begin{array}{|l|l|}
\hline
\text{Column-I} & \text{Column-II} \\
\hline
\text{P : Horton equation} & \text{I: Precipitation} \\
\hline
\text{Q : Muskingum method} & \text{II: Flood frequency} \\
\hline
\text{R : Penman method} & \text{III: Evapotranspiration} \\
\hline
 & \text{IV : Infiltration} \\

solution: Horton's equation is used to calculate total infiltration. Muskingum method is used in flood response analysis in channels. Penman equation is used to calculate potential evapotranspiration.

solution: In hauled container system, 'Haul' time includes. question: Question 14 The magnetic bearing of the sun for a location at noon is [latex]183^{\circ} 30^{\prime}[/latex]. If the sun is exactly on the geographic meridian at noon, the magnetic declination of the location is ___
solution: At any place 12 O'clock sun will be exactly over the true meridian of that place. Declination [latex]=183^{\circ} 30^{\prime}-180^{\circ}=3^{\circ} 30^{\prime} \mathrm{W}[/latex] Magnetic declination will be [latex]3^{\circ} 30 \mathrm{~W}[/latex].

question:
Question 15 For the matrix [latex]
[A]=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & -1 & 0 \\
-1 & 2 & -1 \\
0 & -1 & 1
\end{array}\right]
[/latex] which of the following statements is/are TRUE?
solution: [latex]|A|=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & -1 & 0 \\ -1 & 2 & -1 \\ 0 & -1 & 1\end{array}\right|[/latex] [latex]=1(2-1)+1(-1)+0[/latex] [latex]=1-1=0[/latex] So [latex]A X=B[/latex] does not have unique solution because [latex]\rho(A) \lt 3 [/latex] [latex]|A-\lambda|=0 \Rightarrow\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1-\lambda & -1 & 0 \\ -1 & 2-\lambda & -1 \\ 0 & -1 & 1-\lambda\end{array}\right|=0[/latex] [latex](1-\lambda)((2-\lambda)(1-\lambda)-1)+1(-1+\lambda)+0=0[/latex] [latex](1-\lambda)\left(\lambda^{2}-3 \lambda+1\right)-1+\lambda=0[/latex] [latex](1-\lambda)\left(\lambda^{2}-3 \lambda+1-1\right)=0[/latex] [latex](\lambda-1)\left(\lambda^{2}-3 \lambda\right)=0[/latex] [latex]\lambda=0,1,3[/latex] Matrix [latex]A[/latex] has three distinct Eigen values so have three linearly independent eigen vectors. so option (C) is correct. Given matrix is symmetric matrix with real value entries. Hence [latex]A[/latex] is not a positive definite matrix. because [latex]|1|=1 \gt 0[/latex] [latex]\left|\begin{array}{cc}1 & -1 \\ -1 & 2\end{array}\right|=2-1=1>0[/latex] [latex]\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & -1 & 0 \\ -1 & 2 & -1 \\ 0 & -1 & 1\end{array}\right|=0[/latex] (which is not positive) Hence option (D) is incorrect.

options.B: [latex][A]\{X\}=\{b\}[/latex] does not have a unique solution

question: Question 17 With regard to the shear design of RCC beams, which of the following statements is/are TRUE?
solution: Option A is true, because when the area of shear reinforcement is large i.e. in case of excessive shear reinforcement, concrete becomes stronger is diagonal tension on failure compared to diagonal compression failure and compression failure may occur before the shear reinforcement has yielded. Option '[latex]B[/latex]' is true because for beams without shear reinforcement, once the flexural crack crosses the longitudinal reinforcement, the propagation of crack will be sudden and there can be brittle failure. Option '[latex]C[/latex]' is not true, as main reinforcement increases the shear resitance by providing dowel action, limiting crack width and by increasing the depth of concrete. Design shear strength of concrete is a function of grade of concree and percentage tensile reinforcement. Option 'D' is true, as for beams with varying depth, nominal shear stress, [latex]\tau_{v}=\frac{V_{u} \pm \frac{M_{u} \tan \beta}{d}}{b d}([/latex] clause 40.1.1, IS456: 2000) it is dependent on both the design shear force and design bending moment. Hence, options (A), (B) and (D) are true.

options.A: Excessive shear reinforcement can lead to compression failure in concrete
options.B: Beams without shear reinforcement, even if adequately designed for flexure, can have brittle failure
options.C: The main (longitudinal) reinforcement plays no role in the shear resistance of beam
options.D: As per IS456:2000, the nominal shear stress in the beams of varying depth depends on both the design shear force as well as the design bending moment

question: Question 20 As per the Indian Roads Congress guidelines (IRC 86: 2018), extra widening depends on which of the following parameters?
solution: As per IRC [latex]86: 2018[/latex] Clause 8.6 Widening of Carriageway on Curves: At sharp horizontal curves, it is necessary to widen the carriageway to provide for safe passage of vehicles. The widening required has two components: (i) mechanical widening to components for the extra width occupied by a vehicle on the curve due to tracking of the rare wheels, and (ii) psychological widening to permit easy crossing of vehicles since vehicles in a lane tend to wander more on a curve than on a straight reach. On two-lane or wider roads, it is necessary that both the above components should be fully catered for so that the lateral clearance between vehicles of curves is maintained equal to the clearance available on straight. Position of single-lane roads however is somewhat different. Since during crossing maneuvers outer wheels of vehicles have in any case to use the shoulder whether on the straight or on the curve. It is, therefore sufficient on single lane roads if only the mechanical component of widening is taken into account. Based on the above considerations, the extra width of carriageway to be provided at horizontal curves on single and two-lane roads is given in Table For multi-lane roads, the pavement widening may be calculated by adding half the widening for two-lane roads to each lane. Table : Extra width of Pavement at Horizontal Curves

question: Question 21 The steady-state temperature distribution in a square plate [latex]A B C D[/latex] is governed by the 2-dimensional Laplace equation. The side [latex]A B[/latex] is kept at a temperature of [latex]100{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex] and the other three sides are kept at a temperature of [latex]0{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex]. Ignoring the effect of discontinuities in the boundary conditions at the corners, the steady-state temperature at the center of the plate is obtained as  [latex]T_0 ^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex]. Due to symmetry, the steady-state temperature at the center will be same [latex]\left(\mathrm{T_0}{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)[/latex], when any one side of the square is kept at a temperature of [latex]100{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex] and the remaining three sides are kept at a temperature of [latex]0{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex]. Using the principle of superposition, the value of [latex]T_0[/latex] is ___ (rounded off to two decimal places).
solution:
We know, Laplace equation in two dimensional on a unit square with Dirichlet boundary condition : [latex]
\frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial x^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial y^{2}}=0, \quad 0 \lt (x, y) \lt 1
[/latex] This Laplace equation is called harmonic function. Solution of Laplace equation, [latex]u(x, y)=\left(C_{1} \cos \beta x+C_{2} \sin \beta x\right)\left(C_{3} e^{\text {By }}+C_{4} e^{-\beta y}\right)[/latex] Let square [latex]A B C D[/latex] is unit square. Now, given [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& u(x, 0)=0 \\
& u(0, y)=0 \\
& u(1, y)=0 \\
& u(x, 1)=100
\end{aligned}
[/latex] For [latex]u(x, 0)=0[/latex] [latex]\quad 0=\left(C_{1} \cos \beta x+0\right)(C_3+C_4)[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad \mathrm{C}_{3}=-\mathrm{C}_{4}[/latex] For [latex]u(0, y)=0[/latex]; [latex]0=\left(C_{1}+0\right)\left(C_{3} e^{\beta y}+C_{4} e^{-\beta y}\right)[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad \mathrm{C}_{1}=0[/latex] Now, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
u(x, y) & =0+C_{2} \sin \beta x\left(C_{3} e^{\beta y}+C_{4} e^{-\beta y}\right) \\
& =a_{x} \sin \beta x\left(e^{\beta y}-e^{-\beta y}\right) \quad ...(1)
\end{aligned}
[/latex] [latex]\left[\because \mathrm{C}_{3}=-\mathrm{C}_{4}\right.[/latex] and Let [latex]\left.\mathrm{C}_{2} \mathrm{C}_{3}=\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{x}}\right][/latex] For [latex]u(1, y)=0[/latex] [latex]
0=a_{x} \sin \beta x\left(e^{\beta y}-e^{\beta y}\right)
[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad \beta=\mathrm{n} \pi[/latex] For [latex]u(x, 1)=100[/latex] [latex]a_{x} \sin n\pi x\left(e^{n\pi}-e^{-n \pi}\right)=100[/latex] [latex]
a_{x}=\frac{100}{\sin n\pi x\left(e^{n\pi}-e^{-n \pi}\right)}
[/latex] From eqn. (1), we get [latex]
\begin{gathered}
u(x, y)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty }\frac{100}{\sin n \pi x\left(e^{n\pi}-e^{-n\pi}\right)} \times \sin n\pi x\left(e^{n \pi y}-e^{- n\pi y}\right) \\
=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty }\frac{100}{\left(e^{n\pi}-e^{-n \pi}\right)}\left[e^{n\pi y}-e^{-n\pi y}\right]
\end{gathered}
[/latex] Now, at mid point [latex](x, y)=\left(\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right)[/latex] [latex] u\left(\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right)=T_{0} \text { [given] } [/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
T_0&=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty }\frac{100}{\left(\mathrm{e}^{n\pi}-\mathrm{e}^{-n\pi}\right)}\left[\mathrm{e}^{n\pi / 2}-\mathrm{e}^{-n\pi / 2}\right] \\
&=100\left [ \left ( \frac{\mathrm{e}^{\pi / 2}-\mathrm{e}^{-\pi / 2}}{\mathrm{e}^{\pi}-\mathrm{e}^{-\pi}} \right )  +\left ( \frac{\mathrm{e}^{\pi}-\mathrm{e}^{-\pi}}{\mathrm{e}^{2\pi}-\mathrm{e}^{-2\pi}} \right )+...\right ]\\
&=100\left [ \frac{1}{(\mathrm{e}^{\pi / 2}-\mathrm{e}^{-\pi / 2})}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{e}^{\pi}-\mathrm{e}^{-\pi}}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{e}^{3\pi / 2}-\mathrm{e}^{-3\pi / 2}} +...(neglect) \right ]\\
&=100[0.199+0.043+0.008]\\
&\approx 25^{\circ}C
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 22 An unconfined compression strength test was conducted on a cohesive soil. The test specimen failed at an axial stress of [latex]76 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex]. The undrained cohesion (in [latex]\mathrm{kPa}[/latex], in integer) of the soil is ___
solution: UCS Test : [latex]\sigma_{3}=0[/latex] [Cell pressure] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Axial stress [latex]=[/latex] Deviatoric stress [latex]=\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{3}=\sigma_{1}[/latex] Given, [latex]\sigma_{1}=76 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] We know, [latex]\sigma_{1}=\sigma_{3} \tan ^{2}\left(45^{\circ}+\frac{\phi}{2}\right)+2 C \tan \left(45^{\circ}+\frac{\phi}{2}\right)[/latex] [latex][\mathrm{C}=[/latex] Undrained cohesion, [latex]\phi=0[/latex] (Cohesive soil)] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad \sigma_{1}=2 \mathrm{C}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad 76=2 \mathrm{C}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow  \quad C=38 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex]

The absolute pressure at [latex]X[/latex] is [latex]\mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] (round off to one decimal place). Question 24 For the elevation and temperature data given in the table, the existing lapse rate in the environment is ___ [latex]{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C} / 100 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] (round off to two decimal places). [latex]

\begin{array}{|l|l|}
\hline
\begin{array}{l}\text {Evaluation from} \\ \text {ground level}(\mathrm{m})\end{array} & \text{Temperature }\left({ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right) \\
\hline
5 & 14.2 \\
\hline
325 & 16.9 \\
\hline
\end{array}
[/latex]
solution: Lapse rate, [latex]\lambda=\frac{\text { Difference in Temperature }}{\text { Difference in height }}=\frac{\Delta \mathrm{T}}{\Delta \mathrm{H}}[/latex] [latex]\lambda=\frac{\Delta \mathrm{T}}{\Delta \mathrm{H}}=\frac{16.9-14.2}{325-5}[/latex] [latex]\lambda=0.0084375^{\circ} \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{m}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad \lambda=\frac{0.0084375 \times 100}{100 \mathrm{~m}}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad \lambda=\frac{0.084375^{\circ} \mathrm{C}}{100 \mathrm{~m}}=0.84^{\circ} \mathrm{C} / 100 \mathrm{~m}[/latex]

question: Question 25 If the size of the ground area is [latex]6 \mathrm{~km} \times 3 \mathrm{~km}[/latex] and the corresponding photo size in the aerial photograph is [latex]30 \mathrm{~cm} \times 15 \mathrm{~cm}[/latex], then the scale of the photograph is 1 : ____ (in integer).

Question 26 The solution of the differential equation. [latex]
\frac{d^{3} y}{d x^{3}}-5.5 \frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}+9.5 \frac{d y}{d x}-5 y=0
[/latex] is expressed as [latex]y=C_{1} e^{2.5 x}+C_{2} e^{\alpha . x}+C_{3} e^{\beta x}[/latex], where [latex]\mathrm{C}_{1}, \mathrm{C}_{2}, \mathrm{C}_{3}[/latex] and [latex]\alpha[/latex] and [latex]\beta[/latex] are constants, with [latex]\alpha[/latex] and [latex]\beta[/latex] being distinct and not equal to 2.5. which of the following options is correct for the values of [latex]\alpha[/latex] and [latex]\beta[/latex] ?
solution:
The differential eqn. can be written as : [latex]
D^{3}-5.5 D^{2}+9.5 D-5=0
[/latex] Solving we get, [latex]
D=1,2,2.5
[/latex] Hence, the solution is given as [latex]
y=C_{1} e^{2.5 x}+C_{2} e^{1 x}+C_{3} e^{2 x}
[/latex] Comparing we get, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& \alpha=1 \\
& \beta=2
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Hence, option (A) is correct.

question: Question 27 Two vectors [latex]\left[\begin{array}{llll}2 & 1 & 0 & 3\end{array}\right]^{\top}[/latex] and [latex]\left[\begin{array}{llll}1 & 0 & 1 & 2\end{array}\right]^{\top}[/latex] belong to the null space of a [latex]4 \times 4[/latex] matrix of rank 2 . Which one of the following vectors also belongs to the null space?

solution: We know, cholesky decomposition, [latex]A=LL^{T}[/latex] Where, [latex]L=[/latex] lower tringular matrix [latex]\left[\begin{array}{ll}a_{11} & a_{12} \\ a_{21} & a_{22}\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc}L_{11} & 0 \\ L_{21} & L_{22}\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{cc}\mathrm{L}_{11} & L_{21} \\ 0 & L_{22}\end{array}\right][/latex] [latex]\left[\begin{array}{cc}8 & -5 \\ -5 & \mathrm{a}_{22}\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc}\mathrm{L}_{11}^{2} & \mathrm{~L}_{11} \mathrm{~L}_{21} \\ \mathrm{~L}_{11} \mathrm{~L}_{21} & \mathrm{~L}_{21}^{2}+\mathrm{L}_{22}^{2}\end{array}\right][/latex] On comparison on both sides, [latex]\mathrm{L}_{11}=\sqrt{8}=2 \sqrt{2}[/latex] [latex]and,\;\; L_{11} L_{21}=-5[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{L}_{21}=\frac{-5}{2 \sqrt{2}}[/latex] [latex]and,\;\; a_{22}=L_{21}^{2}+L_{22}^{2}[/latex] [latex]=\left(\frac{-5}{2 \sqrt{2}}\right)^{2}+1.968^{2}[/latex] [latex]=6.998 \approx 7[/latex]

Question 35 Match the following air pollutants with the most appropriate adverse health effects: [latex]

\begin{array}{|l|l|}
\hline 
\textbf{Air pollutant} & \textbf{Health effect to human and/or test animal} \\
\hline
\text{(P) Aromatic hydrocarbons} & \text{(I) Reduce the capability of the blood to carry oxygen} \\
\hline
\text{(Q) Carbon monoxide} & \text{(II) Bronchitis and pulmonary emphysema}\\
\hline
\text{(R) Sulfur oxides}& \text{(III) Damage of chromosomes} \\
\hline
\text{(S) Ozone} & \text{(IV) Carcinogenic effect} \\
\hline
\end{array}

[/latex]
solution: Aromatic hydrocarbons such as 3, 4benzpyrene, other polycyclic organic compounds which are originated due to incomplete combustion of hydrocarbons are considered to be carcinogenic agents. These are responsible for cancer. Sulphur dioxide [latex]\left(\mathrm{SO}_{2}\right)[/latex] : It is an irritant gas which effects mucous membrane when inhaled. It leads to bronchial spasms. Asthma patients are badly affected. Carbon Monoxide (CO) : Carbon monoxide has a strong affinity for combining with the haemoglobin of the blood to form carboxyhemoglobin, [latex]\mathrm{COHb}[/latex]. This reduces the ability of the haemoglobin to carry oxygen to the body tissues. CO has about two hundred time the affinity of oxygen for attaching itself to the haemoglobin, so that low levels of CO can still result in high levels of [latex]\mathrm{COHb}[/latex]. Carbon monoxide also affects the central nervous system. Ozone [latex]\left(\mathrm{O}_{3}\right)[/latex] can damage the tissue of the respiratory tract, causing inflammation and irritation, and result in symptoms such as coughing, chest tightness and worsening of asthma symptoms. In addition, ozone causes substantial damage to crops, forests and native plants.

question: Question 38 In the context of water and wastewater treatments, the correct statements are:
solution: Total dissolved solids comprise of inorganic salts, principally calcium, magnesium, potassium, sodium bicarbonates, chlorides, sulfates and some small amount of organic matter that are dissolved in water. Hardness is due to presence of multivalent cations. In most cases, it is due to the presence of soluble bicarbonates, chlorides and sulfates of calcium and magnesium. Too much phosphorous can cause increased growth of algae and large aquatic plants. It can result in decreased levels of dissolved oxygen and the process is called 'Eutrophication'. Ammonia creates a large chlorine demand, as the ammonia is converted to nitrogen gas and the chlorine becomes chloride during disinfection of water by chlorination. Presence of particulate matter decreases the effectiveness of UV disinfection or chlorine disinfection by shielding the targeted microorganisms.

options.A: particulate matter may shield microorganisms during disinfection
options.C: phosphorous stimulates algal and aquatic growth
options.D: calcium and magnesium increase hardness and total dissolved solids

question: Question 39 Which of the following statements is/are TRUE for the aerobic composting of sewage sludge?
solution:
A bulking agent (wood ships shredded leaves or types) is intended to support the structure of sludge by increasing its porosity to encourage effective aeration. In-vessel composting systems can be divided into plug flow and agitated bed modes. In plug flow mode, the relationship between particles in the composting mass stays the same through the process and the system operates on first-in, first-out principle. In an agitated bed system, composting material is mixed mechanically during the processing. The heat produced in aquatic composting cause any surplus moisture to be extracted as water vapour and hence no leachate is produced. Actinomycetes are aerobic, spore forming positive bacteria. These are thermophilic species and their development depends on aerobic conditions, temperature and water content. The heat produced in aerobic
composting helps support the growth of these species. Leachate can generated from vegetable wastes.

options.A: Bulking agent is added during the composting process to reduce the porosity of the solid mixture
options.B: Leachate can be generated during composting
options.C: Actinomycetes are involved in the process
options.D: In-vessel composting systems cannot be operated in the plug-flow mode

question: Question 40 The figure presents the time-space diagram for when the traffic on a highway is suddenly stopped for a certain time and then released. Which of the following statements are true?
solution: Any vertical line drawn in the graph which cuts arrow lines give positions of vehicles in different regions at a particular time. Slope of a line in a region represents speed of vehicles in that particular region. From the Plot : 1. Distance between position of vehicles in region ' [latex]P[/latex] ' is greater than that in region [latex]R \Rightarrow[/latex] Density in region ' [latex]P[/latex] ' is greater than that in region ' [latex]R[/latex] '. 2. Slope of lines in region ' [latex]Q[/latex] ' [latex]=0 \Rightarrow[/latex] Speed of vehicles in region ' [latex]\mathrm{Q}[/latex] ' is zero. 3. Slope of lines in region ' [latex]P[/latex] ' is greater than in region ' [latex]R[/latex] ' [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] speed of vehicles in region ' [latex]P[/latex] ' is greater than in region ' [latex]R[/latex] '. 4. Since vehicles in region ' [latex]Q[/latex] ' are stationary, flow or volume in region ' [latex]Q[/latex] ' is zero and hence lower than in region [latex]\mathrm{P}[/latex] or region [latex]\mathrm{R}[/latex]. And density in region ' [latex]\mathrm{Q}[/latex] ' is higher than in region [latex]\mathrm{P}[/latex] or region [latex]\mathrm{R}[/latex]. 5. Boundary between region ' [latex]P[/latex] and ' [latex]R[/latex] ' represents 'forward moving slope wave' means slope is positive. i.e. [latex]\quad[/latex] slope [latex]=\frac{q_{R}-q_{P}}{K_{R}-K_{P}} \gt 0[/latex] q - Flow [latex]\mathrm{K}[/latex] - Density. Since [latex]\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{R}} \gt \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{P}}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \mathrm{q}_{\mathrm{R}}[/latex] should be greater than [latex]\mathrm{q}_{\mathrm{P}}[/latex]. [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] Volume/flow in region ' [latex]R[/latex] ' is higher than in Region 'P'.

options.A: Speed is higher in Region [latex]\mathrm{R}[/latex] than in Region [latex]\mathrm{P}[/latex]
options.B: Volume is lower in Region [latex]Q[/latex] than in Region [latex]P[/latex]
options.C: Volume is higher in Region [latex]\mathrm{R}[/latex] than in Region [latex]\mathrm{P}[/latex]
options.D: Density is higher in Region [latex]\mathrm{Q}[/latex] than in Region [latex]\mathrm{R}[/latex]

question: Question 44 For the frame shown in the figure (not to scale), all members [latex](A B, B C, C D, G B[/latex], and [latex]C H)[/latex] have the same length, [latex]L[/latex] and flexural rigidity, El. The joints at [latex]B[/latex] and [latex]C[/latex] are rigid joints, and the supports [latex]A[/latex] and [latex]D[/latex] are fixed supports. Beams GB and [latex]\mathrm{CH}[/latex] carry uniformly distributed loads of [latex]w[/latex] per unit length. The magnitude of the moment reaction at [latex]A[/latex] is [latex]\mathrm{wL}^{2} / \mathrm{k}[/latex]. What is the value of [latex]\mathrm{k}[/latex] (in integer) ? ____
solution:
Due to symmetry, slope at mid of [latex]B C[/latex] is zero and can be taken as slider at point [latex]O[/latex] Distribution factors: [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{BA}} & =\frac{4 \mathrm{EI} / \mathrm{L}}{4 \mathrm{EI} / \mathrm{L}+\mathrm{EI} /(\mathrm{L} / 2)}=\frac{2}{3} \\
\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{BO}}&= 1-\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{BA}} \\
& =1-2 / 3=1 / 3 \\
\therefore \quad \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{BA}} & =\frac{\mathrm{WL}^{2}}{2} \times \frac{2}{3}=\frac{\mathrm{WL}^{2}}{3} \\
\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{AB}} & =\frac{\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{BA}}}{2}=\frac{\mathrm{WL}^{2} / 3}{2}=\frac{\mathrm{WL}^{2}}{6} \\
& \therefore \mathrm{K}=6
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 45 Consider the singly reinforced section of a cantilever concrete beam under bending, as shown in the figure (M25 grade concrete, Fe415 grade steel). The ultimate moment of resistance for the section by the Limit State Method is ____ kN.m (round off to one decimal place). [Note: Here, As is the total area of tension steel bars, [latex]b[/latex] is the width of the section, [latex]d[/latex] is the effective depth of the bars, [latex]f_{c k}[/latex] is the characteristic compressive cube strength of concrete, [latex]f_{y}[/latex] is the yield stress of steel, and [latex]\mathrm{xu}[/latex] is the depth of neutral axis.]
solution:
Given data, Grade of concrete [latex]=[/latex] M25 Grade of Steel [latex]=\mathrm{Fe} 415[/latex] Effective depth, [latex]d=600-45=555 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] [latex]
A_{s}=3 \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times(28)^{2}=1847.26 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}
[/latex] From Compression [latex]=[/latex] Tension Depth of neutral axis, [latex]x_{u}=\frac{0.87 f_{y} A_{s}}{0.36 f_{c k} b}=\frac{0.87 \times 415 \times 1847.26}{0.36 \times 25 \times 300}  =247.02 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] Limiting depth of neutral axis, [latex]x_{u, l i m}=0.48 \mathrm{~d}[/latex]

[latex]
=0.48 \times 555=266.40 \mathrm{~mm}
[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] Section is under reinforced. Ultimate moment of resistance [latex]
=0.36 f_{c k} b x_{u}\left(d-0.42 x_{u}\right)
[/latex] [latex]=0.36 \times 25 \times 300 \times 247.02 \times[/latex]

[latex](555-0.42 \times 247.02) \times 10^{-6}[/latex] [latex]=301.0[/latex] (after rounding off to one decimal place).

question: Question 46 A [latex]\quad  2 \mathrm{D}[/latex] thin plate with modulus of elasticity, [latex]E=1.0[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex], and Poisson's ratio, [latex]\mu=0.5[/latex], is in plane stress condition. The displacement field in the plate is given by [latex]\mu=C^{2} y[/latex] and [latex]v=0[/latex], where us and [latex]v[/latex] are displacements (in [latex]m[/latex] ) along the [latex]X[/latex] and [latex]Y[/latex] directions, respectively, and [latex]C[/latex] is constant (in [latex]\mathrm{m}^{-2}[/latex] ). The distance [latex]x[/latex] and [latex]y[/latex] along [latex]X[/latex] an [latex]Y[/latex], respectively, are in [latex]\mathrm{m}[/latex]. The stress in the [latex]X[/latex] direction is [latex]\sigma_{x x}=40 x y \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex], and the shear stress is [latex]\tau_{x y}=a x^{2} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex]. What is the value of [latex]\alpha[/latex] (in [latex]\mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{4}[/latex], in integer) ?
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
& \epsilon_{x}=\frac{\sigma_{x}}{E}-\frac{\mu \sigma_{y}}{E} \\
& \epsilon_{y}=\frac{\sigma_{y}}{E}-\frac{\mu \sigma_{x}}{E} \\
& \tau_{x y}=\frac{\gamma_{x y}}{G_{1}} \\
& G=\frac{E}{2(1+\mu)} \\
& \epsilon_{x}+\mu \epsilon_{y}=\frac{\sigma_{x}}{E}-\frac{\mu \sigma_{y}}{E}+\frac{\mu \sigma_{y}}{E}-\frac{\mu^{2} \sigma_{x}}{E} \\
& \epsilon_{x}+\mu \epsilon_{y}=\frac{\sigma_{x}}{E}\left(1-\mu^{2}\right) \\
& \sigma_{x}=\frac{E}{1-\mu^{2}}\left[\epsilon_{x}+\mu \epsilon_{y}\right] \\
& \sigma_{x}=\frac{E}{1-\mu^{2}}\left[\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}+\mu \frac{\partial v}{\partial y}\right] \\
& \sigma_{x}=\frac{E}{1-\mu^{2}}[2(x y+0)] \\
& \sigma_{x}=\frac{2 \mathrm{ECxy}}{1-\mu^{2}} \\
& \sigma_{x}=40 x y \text { (Given) } \\
& \Rightarrow \frac{2 \mathrm{ECxy}}{1-\mu^{2}}=40 x y \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{2 \mathrm{EC}}{1-\mu^{2}}=40 \\
& Y_{x y}=\frac{\tau_{x}}{G} \\
& G \gamma_{x y}=\tau_{x y} \\
& \frac{E}{2(1+\mu)}\left[\frac{\partial u}{\partial y}+\frac{\partial v}{\partial x}\right]=\tau_{x y} \\
& \frac{E}{2(1+\mu)}\left[C^{2}+0\right]=\alpha x^{2} \\
& \alpha=\frac{C E}{2(1+\mu)} \\
& \alpha=\frac{40\left(1-\mu^{2}\right)}{2 E} \frac{E}{2(1+\mu)} \\
& \alpha=10(1-\mu)=10(1-0.5)=5
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 47 An idealized frame supports a load as shown in the figure. The horizontal component of the force transferred from the horizontal member PQ to the vertical member [latex]\mathrm{RS}[/latex] at [latex]\mathrm{P}[/latex] is [latex]\mathrm{N}[/latex] (round off to one decimal place).

Question 48 A square footing is to be designed to carry a column load of [latex]500 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] which is resting on a soil stratum having the following average properties: bulk unit weight [latex]=19 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex]; angle of internal friction [latex]=0^{\circ}[/latex], and cohesion [latex]=25 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex]. Considering the depth of the footing as [latex]1 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] and adopting Meyerhof's bearing capacity theory with a factor of safety of 3 , the width of the footing (in [latex]\mathrm{m}[/latex] ) is ____ (round off to one decimal place) [Assume the applicable shape and depth factor values as unity; ground water level at greater depth.]
solution:
As per Meyerhoff's approach [latex]
q_{u}=C N_{c}\left[i_{c} S_{c} d_{c}\right]+q N_{q}\left[{ }_{q} S_{q} d_{r}\right]+\frac{1}{2} \beta \gamma N_{r}\left[i_{r} S_{r} d_{r}\right]
[/latex] Given; shape factor [latex]S_{c}, S_{q}, S_{r}=1[/latex] depth factor [latex]d_{c}, d_{v}, d_{r}=1[/latex] Assuming no inclination of loading hence [latex]i_{c} i_{q} i_{r}=1[/latex] For [latex]\phi=0^{\circ}[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{c}}=5.14 \\
& N_{\mathrm{q}}=1 \\
& N_{r}=0 \\
& \therefore \quad \mathrm{q}_{\mathrm{u}}=25 \times 5.14 \times 1 \times 1 \times 1+19 \times 1 \times \\
& 1 \times 1 \times 1 \\
& =147.5 \mathrm{kPa} \\
& \mathrm{q}_{\mathrm{nu}}=\mathrm{q}_{\mathrm{u}}-\mathrm{rD}_{\mathrm{f}} \\
& =147.5-19 \times 1 \\
& =128.5 \mathrm{kPa}
\end{aligned}
[/latex] [latex]q_{n s}=\frac{q_{n u}}{F O S}=\frac{128.5}{3}=42.83 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] Hence, [latex]\frac{500}{B^{2}} \leq 42.83[/latex] or

[latex]B \geq 3.416 m[/latex] Hence [latex]B=3.4 m[/latex]

Question 50 For the flow setup shown in the figure (not to scale), the hydraulic conductivities of the two soil samples, Soil 1 and Soil 2, are [latex]10 \mathrm{~mm} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] and [latex]1 \mathrm{~mm} / \mathrm{s}[/latex], respectively. Assume the unit weight of water as [latex]10 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] and ignore the velocity head. At steady state, what is the total head (in [latex]m[/latex], rounded off to two decimal places) at any point located at the junction of the two samples? ____

Question 51 A consolidated drained (CD) triaxial test was carried out on a sand sample with the known effective shear strength parameters, [latex]C^{\prime}=0[/latex] and [latex]\phi^{\prime}=30^{\circ}[/latex]. In the test, prior to the failure, when the sample was undergoing axial compression under constant cell pressure, the drainage valve was accidentally closed. At the failure, [latex]360 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] deviatoric stress was recorded along with [latex]70 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] pore water pressure. If the test is repeated without such error, and no back pressure is applied in either of the tests, what is the deviatoric stress (in [latex]\mathrm{kPa}[/latex], in integer) at the failure? _____
solution:
We know that, [latex]\bar{\sigma}_{1 F}=\bar{\sigma}_{3 \mathrm{~F}} \tan ^{2}\left(45+\frac{\phi^{\prime}}{2}\right)+20 \tan \left(45+\frac{\phi^{\prime}}{2}\right)[/latex] Assuming [latex]c^{\prime}=0[/latex] under both the conditions when drainage line in suddenly dosed. [latex]
\left(\sigma_{\mathrm{cf}}+360-70\right)=\left(\sigma_{\mathrm{cy}}-70\right) \tan ^{2} 60+0\;\;\;...(i)
[/latex] When drainage is open and assuming the confining stress [latex]\left(\sigma_{\mathrm{cf}}\right)[/latex]. [latex]
\left[\left(\sigma_{\mathrm{cf}}+\sigma_{2}\right)-0\right]=\left[\sigma_{\mathrm{cf}}-0\right] \tan ^{2} 60^{\circ}+0 \;\;\;...(ii)
[/latex] From (i) and (ii), we get [latex]
\begin{aligned}
290-\sigma_{2} & =-70 \times \tan ^{2} 60^{\circ} \\
290-\sigma_{d} & =-210 \\
\sigma_{d} &=500 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question:
Question 52 A catchment may be idealized as a circle of radius [latex]30 \mathrm{~km}[/latex]. There are five rain gauges, one at the center of the catchment and four on the boundary (equi-spaced), as shown in the figure (not to scale). The annual rainfall recorded at these gauges in a particular year are given below. [latex]

\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
Gauge & \mathrm{G}_{1} & \mathrm{G}_{2} & \mathrm{G}_{3} & \mathrm{G}_{4} & \mathrm{G}_{5} \\
\hline
Rainfall (mm) & 910 & 930 & 925 & 895 & 905 \\
\hline
\end{array}

[/latex] Using the Thiessen polygon method, what is the average rainfall (in [latex]\mathrm{mm}[/latex], rounded off to two decimal places) over the catchment in that year ? ___
solution:
Radius of basin [latex]=30 \mathrm{~km}[/latex] We know that in Theissen polygon method, the polygons are obtained by joining the perpendicular bisectors of triangles formed, when various rain gauge stations are joined. The Theissen polygon in the given basin can be drawn as: Area under influence of station GI [latex]=30 \times 30=900 \mathrm{~km}^{2}[/latex] Area under influence of stations G2, G3, G4, G5 [latex]=\frac{\pi \times 30^{2}-900}{4}[/latex] [latex]=481.86 \mathrm{~km}^{2}[/latex] mean rainfall [latex]=\frac{\begin{array}{c}910 \times 900+481.86 \times 930+ \\ 481.86 \times 925+481.86 \times 895+ \\ 481.86 \times 905\end{array}}{900+481.86 \times 4}[/latex]

[latex]=912.56 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex]

question: Question 53 The cross-section of a small river is sub-divided into seven segments of width [latex]1.5 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] each. The average depth, and velocity at different depths were measured during a field campaign at the middle of each segment width. The discharge computed by the velocity area method for the given data is ____ [latex]\mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] (round off to one decimal place).
solution:
Average width for 1 st land last sections, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\omega}_{1}=\bar{\omega}_{\mathrm{n}} & =\frac{\left(\omega_{1}+\frac{\omega_{2}}{2}\right)^{2}}{2 \omega_{1}} \\
& =\frac{\left(1.5+\frac{1.5}{2}\right)^{2}}{2 \times 1.5} \\
& =1.6875 \mathrm{~m}
\end{aligned}
[/latex] [latex]

\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\begin{array}{l}\text { Avg. width } \\ \text { (m) } \\ \text { (1) }\end{array} & \begin{array}{l}\text { Avg. Depth } \\ \text { (m) } \\ \text { (2) }\end{array} & \begin{array}{l}\text { Avg. Velocity } \\ \text { (m/s) } \\ \text { (3) }\end{array} & \begin{array}{c}\text { Segmental } \\ \text { discharge } \\ \left(\mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}\right)=(1) \times(2) \times(3)\end{array} \\
\hline
1.6875 & 0.40 & 0.40 & 0.270 \\
\hline
1.5 & 0.70 & \frac{0.76+0.70}{2}=0.73 & 0.767 \\
\hline
1.5 & 1.20 & \frac{1.19+1.13}{2}=1.16 & 2.088 \\
\hline
1.5 & 1.40 & \frac{1.25+1.10}{2}=1.175 & 2.467 \\
\hline
1.5 & 1.10 & \frac{1.13+1.09}{2}=1.11 & 1.831 \\
\hline
1.5 & 0.80 & \frac{0.69+0.65}{2}=0.67 & 0.804 \\
\hline
1.6875 & 0.45 & 0.42 & 0.319 \\
\hline
 &  &  & \Sigma=8.546 \\
\hline
\end{array}

[/latex]

Question 57 Kind : _______ : : Often : Seldom
solution:
Often and seldom are antonyms. Hence, correct
option will be the antonym of kind i.e. Cruel.

Question 61 Elvesland is a country that has peculiar beliefs and practices. They express almost
all their emotions by gifting flowers. For instance, if anyone gifts a white flower to
someone, then it is always taken to be a declaration of one's love for that person. In
a similar manner, the gifting of a yellow flower to someone often means that one is
angry with that person. Based only on the information provided above, which one of the following sets of
statement(s) can be logically inferred with certainty? (i) In Elvesland, one always declares one's love by gifting a white flower. (ii) In Elvesland, all emotions are declared by gifting flowers. (iii) In Elvesland, sometimes one expresses one's anger by gifting a flower that is
not yellow. (iv) In Elvesland, sometimes one expresses one's love by gifting a white flower.

Question 62 Three husband-wife pairs are to be seated at a circular table that has six identical chairs. Seating arrangements are defined only by the relative position of the people. How many seating arrangements are possible such that every husband sits next to his wife?

Question 63 Based only on the following passage, which one of the options can be inferred with certainty? When the congregation sang together, Apenyo would also join, though her little screams were not quite audible because of the group singing. But whenever there was a special number, trouble would begin; Apenyo would try singing along, much to the embarrassment of her mother. After two or three such mortifying Sunday evenings, the mother stopped going to church altogether until Apenyo became older and learnt to behave. At home too, Apenyo never kept quiet; she hummed or made up silly songs to sing by herself, which annoyed her mother at times but most often made her become pensive. She was by now convinced that her daughter had inherited her love of singing from her father who had died unexpectedly away from home. [Excerpt from These Hills Called Home by Temsula Ao]

options.A:
The mother was embarrassed about her
daughter's singing at home.
options.B:
The mother's feelings about her daughter's
singing at home were only of annoyance
options.C:
The mother was not sure if Apenyo
had inherited her love of singing from her
father.
options.D:
When Apenyo hummed at home, her mother
tended to become thoughtful.

question: Question 64 If [latex]x[/latex] satisfies the equation [latex]4^{8^{x}}=256[/latex], then [latex]x[/latex] is equal to
solution:
[latex]
4^{8^{x}}=256
[/latex] [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Taking log to the base 4 . on both side. [latex]
8^{x}=\log _{4} 256=4
[/latex] Taking lot to the base 8 on both sides, we get [latex]
\begin{aligned}
x & =\log _{8} 4 \\
& =\log _{2^{3}} 2^{2} \\
x & =\frac{2}{3}
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 65 Consider a spherical globe rotating about an axis passing through its poles. There are three points [latex]P[/latex], [latex]\mathrm{Q}[/latex], and [latex]\mathrm{R}[/latex] situated respectively on the equator, the north pole, and midway between the equator and the north pole in the northern hemisphere. Let [latex]P[/latex], [latex]\mathrm{Q}[/latex], and [latex]\mathrm{R}[/latex] move with speeds [latex]v_{P}, v_{Q}[/latex], and [latex]v_{R}[/latex], respectively. Which one of the following options is CORRECT?
solution: Velocity, [latex]V=\omega r[/latex]. Here, [latex]\omega=[/latex] constant. Hence, more is the distance from the axis of rotation more will be the velocity. [latex]\therefore \quad \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{P}} \gt \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{R}} \gt \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{Q}}[/latex]
